Description: A roughly triangular pierced pebble of dark-red chert which, when held with the dark-red side uppermost, slightly resembles a bull's head. The underside, which is naturally hollowed out, retains the buff coloured cortex. The polish of the stone and the piercing are natural. It is unclear whether it was worn as a pendant.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Badari, el-, Deposit or grave 5118
Curator's comments: Found together with two flint flakes and a carved ivory spoon handle (see EA 59654-59656).
Bibliographic references: Andrews 1981 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities. Jewellery I (54)
Brunton & Caton-Thompson 1928 / The Badarian Civilisation and Predynastic Remains near Badari (p. 7 Grave register, pl. V.)
Acquisition name: Donated by: British School of Archaeology, Egypt
